mmc1 mmc1.docx docx 864191 APPLICATION MCAT 114651 114651 S2468-8231(24)00833-2 10.1016/j.mcat.2024.114651 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Influence of temperature, pH, and metal Ions on the activity of reAfXylA11. Note: Panel A illustrates the optimum temperature and thermostability of reAfXylA11. Panel B shows the optimum pH and pH stability of reAfXylA11. Panel C details the effects of different metal ions on enzyme activity. In the optimal assay conditions, the highest activity observed was represented as 100 %. For stability assessments, the performance of the untreated reAfXylA11 under optimal conditions was taken as 100 %. In the assays evaluating the impact of metal ions, the baseline activity of reAfXylA11, untreated and supplemented with an equivalent volume of water under optimal conditions, was established as 100 %. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Hydrolytic products of beechwood xylan by reAfXylA11. Note: HPLC profiles of the beechwood xylan hydrolysates released by reAfXylA11 and the standards (X-X6). X, xylose; X2, xylobiose; X3, xylotriose; X4, xylotetraose; X5, xylopentaose; X6, xylohexaose. The quantified concentrations of X2, X3, X4, X5, and X6 were determined to be 0.251, 0.668, 0.554, 0.534, and 0.484 mg/mL, respectively. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Antioxidant activity of beechwood xylan hydrolysates. Note: Determination of anti-oil oxidation ability (A), ABTS+ scavenging ability (B), scavenging activity against DPPH radicals (C), and iron ion chelating ability (D) of beechwood xylan hydrolysates released by reAfXylA11. Trolox and ascorbic acid (VC) served as the positive control in the assays for anti-oil oxidation potential and ABTS+ radical scavenging capacity, respectively. Butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA) and EDTA were used as the positive control in the assays for DPPH radicals clearance rate and iron ion chelating ability, respectively. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Effects of temperature (A), time (B), and dose (C) on inhibition activity of reAfXylA11 by rePOsXIP. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Inhibition kinetics of reAfXylA11 by rePOsXIP. Note: (A) Lineweaver-Burk plot illustrating the activity of reAfXylA11 in the presence of varying concentrations of rePOsXIP. Symbols represent different doses of rePOsXIP: (■) 0 nM, (●) 79.0 nM, (▲) 158.0 nM, and (▼) 237.0 nM. (B) Determination of the inhibition constant (Ki ) from the secondary plot where the slopes of Lineweaver-Burk plots are plotted against the concentrations of rePOsXIP. The Ki corresponds to the x-intercept of this plot. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Fluorescence quenching and Stern-Volmer analysis of the interaction between reAfXylA11 and rePOsXIP. Note: (A) Fluorescence spectra of reAfXylA11 in presence of increasing concentrations of rePOsXIP: 0, 0.81, 1.62, 2.43, 3.24, 4.05, 4.86, and 5.67 µmol/L. (B) Double logarithmic plot of (F0 - F)/F against rePOsXIP concentration (Q). The association constant (KA) and the number of binding sites (n) were determined to be 6.366 × 105 L.µmol−1 and 1.4, respectively. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Analysis of MD simulations of AfXylA11-OsXIP complex. Note: (A) Plots of root-mean-square deviation (RMSD), (B) radius of gyration (Rg), (C) solvent-accessible surface area (SASA), (D) root-mean-square fluctuation (RMSF). Calculations for RMSD and RMSF focused on the protein's backbone. In panel D, the residues K150-V158 (U-shaped loop Lα4β5 in OsXIP) are highlighted within a red box. These residues exhibit significantly higher RMSF values in the apo-OsXIP state compared to the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex. The Lα4β5 extends into the catalytic groove of AfXylA11, engaging in stable interactions with essential sites within the active cleft. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Free energy landscape and molecular interactions of AfXylA11-OsXIP. Glycoside hydrolase (GH) family 11 Aspergillus fumigatus endo-xylanase A (AfXylA11) was recombinantly expressed in Pichia pastoris X33 and secreted into culture medium. Hydrolysis of beechwood xylan by recombinant AfXylA11 (reAfXylA11) predominantly generated xylooligosaccharides (XOs), chiefly comprising xylotriose (X2) and xylotetraose (X3). These hydrolysates demonstrated significant antioxidant capabilities. Competitive inhibition of reAfXylA11 was observed in the presence of the Oryza sativa xylanase inhibitor protein (OsXIP), with an inhibition constant (Ki ) of 120.98 nM. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and conformational analyses of the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex revealed that the extended loop (Lα4β5, K150-V158) of OsXIP penetrated the active groove of AfXylA11, thereby obstructing xylan from interacting with catalytic sites. The R153 at the bottom of the U-shaped loop, was found to form durable hydrogen bonds with E197 (acid/base catalyst) and Y97 of AfXylA11. Additionally, OsXIP established stable interactions with the “cord” and “thumb” regions of AfXylA11 during MD simulations. The binding free energy of the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex was determined to be -74.3 ± 7.6 kcal/mol, with electrostatic interactions and van der Waals forces being the predominant contributors to enzyme-inhibitor interaction. Further MD simulations demonstrated that the mutation of Y116A or S120A in the “cord” region of AfXylA11 significantly reduced its binding affinity to OsXIP by weakening interface residue interactions. Delving into the conformational dynamics of the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex yields insights into the molecular mechanisms dictating their competitive inhibition. This investigation offers useful basis for engineering mutant xylanases that resist to the inhibitory protein yet retain high catalytic efficacy. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Xylanase OsXIP Competitive inhibition Antioxidant Key interface residue Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Xylan, the principal constituent of hemicellulose, is primarily composed of β-d-xylopyranose units linked by β−1,4-glycosidic bonds, forming its backbone. This complex polysaccharide is divided into two main categories: homo-xylans, which are linear in structure, and hetero-xylans, which include variants such as arabinoxylan, glucuronoxylan, and glucuronoarabinoxylan [1,2]. Due to its complex structure, the breakdown of xylan depends on the coordinated activity of an elaborate network of glycoside hydrolases (GH). The β−1,4-endoxylanase plays a pivotal role in this process, targeting the glycosidic bonds within the main chain of xylan. The endoxylanase is primarily classified into several GH families, notably GH11 and GH10 families [3-5]. Family GH11 xylanases are characterized by their selective substrate specificity, high catalytic efficiency, and relatively low molecular mass (approximately 20 kDa), conferring significant advantages for oligosaccharide production. Family GH11 xylanases exhibit a characteristic β-jelly roll structure, featuring two large β-sheets and a distinct α-helix [6,7]. Xylanase inhibitor proteins (XIs), widely present in cereals such as wheat, barley, oats, rice, and maize, are integral in plant defense against diseases and pests by inhibiting xylanase activity [8-10]. In wheat, three inhibitor proteins, XIP (xylanase inhibitor protein), TLXI (thaumatin-like xylanase inhibitor), and TAXI (Triticum aestivum xylanase inhibitor), have been identified. Cereal-derived XIs selectively inhibit exogenous xylanase activity without impinging on endogenous enzymes [11-13]. XIP-type inhibitors are basic monomeric proteins with a molecular weight of approximately 30 kDa and adopt a (β/α)8 barrel structure. In wheat, the content of XIP-type inhibitors can reach as high as 156–560 µg/g [9,11]. Arabinoxylan in cereals acts as an anti-nutritional factor in poultry. The addition of xylanase to broiler wheat feed can improve its nutritional value. Ponte et al. have found that high doses of wheat xylanase inhibitors in chick diets reduce the effectiveness of Trichoderma reesei xylanase supplementation. There were no significant differences in growth performance or feed conversion rates between the low-dose enzyme supplementation group and the basic diet group in broilers [14]. Incorporating xylanase during dough fermentation enhanced the volume and fluffiness of bread [15,16]. However, the efficacy of Aspergillus niger xylanase in increasing bread volume was significantly attenuated by the presence of the inhibitor protein, TAXI in flour. Utilizing xylanases that are insensitive to these inhibitors or selecting wheat varieties with low levels of inhibitor proteins can improve the baking quality of bread [10]. Historically, XIs were believed to be absent in rice; therefore, early research on XIs focused on wheat sources. However, in 2005, Goesaert et al. isolated such proteins from rice [17]. The XIs identified in rice are exclusively of the XIP type, including OsXIP, riceXIP, and RIXI [18]. The subsequent research has primarily focused on their roles in rice metabolic development and resistance to pathogen invasion [19-22]. The rice XIP-type XIs exhibited competitive inhibition against family GH10 and GH11 xylanases. OsXIP effectively inhibited family GH10 Aspergillus fumigatus xylanase A (AfXylA10) and XYN-LXY_CD [23,24], and riceXIP targeted family GH11 xylanase B from A. niger via competitive inhibition [25]. Additionally, the RIXI has been shown to possess significant inhibitory activity on a range of family GH11 endo-xylanases, impacting the enzymatic hydrolysis of xylan [26,27]. Currently, the three-dimensional structures of the three XIs have not been deposited in the Protein Data Bank (PDB) or the Electron Microscopy Data Bank (EMDB). These proteins share relatively low sequence identity with wheat XIs whose 3D structures are known. The amino acid sequence identity of OsXIP, riceXIP, and RIXI to wheat XIP-I (1OM0) are only 42.7 %, 47.1 %, and 53.9 %, respectively. Xylanase inhibitory proteins (XIs), commonly present in food and feed raw materials, inhibit exogenous xylanases and reduce their effectiveness in industrial applications. By understanding the interaction between XIs and xylanase, technologies such as site-directed mutagenesis and sequence replacement can be employed to engineer mutant xylanases that are insensitive to XIs. These mutant xylanases might efficiently catalyze the hydrolysis of xylan in natural polysaccharide complexes, enhancing their suitability for use in the food and feed industries. In this investigation, the family GH11 endo-xylanase A (AfXylA11) from A. fumigatus was recombinantly expressed. The antioxidant capacity of beechwood xylan hydrolysates produced by recombinant AfXylA11 was assessed. Moreover, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and conformational analysis were employed to elucidate the interaction mechanisms within the OsXIP-AfXylA11 complex, providing insights into the functional dynamics and key interface residues. 2 Materials and methods The cDNA of A. fumigatus JL16 [23] and the genetically engineered P. pastoris strain PPOsXIP15 which produces the recombinant OsXIP (rePOsXIP) [28], are preserved in the laboratory. Beechwood xylan was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The standard xylooligosaccharides (XOs) ranging from xylobiose (X2) to xylohexoase (X6) were purchased from Magezyme. DNA Marker, PCR kit and restriction endonucleases were from TaKaRa. Protein Marker, Primers and DNA sequencing services were provided by Songon Biotech. The culture mediums were from Oxoid. Other reagents used were of analytical grade. Assays were conducted in triplicated, with outcomes were presented as the mean ± standard deviation. 2.1 Secreted expression of afxyla11 in P. pastoris X33 The afxyla11 gene, encoding family GH11 endo-β−1,4-xylanase A, was PCR-amplified using cDNA from A. fumigatus JL16 as the template, with xyla11CP1 (5′-ATGGTTTCTTTCTCCTACCTGC-3′) and xyla11CP2 (5′-CTAATAGACAGTGATGGAAGCAG-3′) as cloning primers. Subsequent to this, specific expression primers, xyla11EP1 (5′-GCAGAATTCGCCCCCGTCGAACCCGAGACC-3′) and xyla11EP2 (5′-AGGCGGCCGCATAGACAGTGATGGAAGCAGATC-3′), were designed to PCR amplify the sequence encoding the mature peptide of AfXylA11, using afxyla11 as the template. The recovered PCR product was digested with EcoRI and NotI and ligated into pPICZαA. The recombinant plasmid pPICZαA-afxyla11 was linearized with SacI and transformed into competent P. pastoris X33 cells. Transformants were cultured on YPD agar supplemented with 100 µg/mL Zeocin and screened via PCR using 5AOX1 and 3AOX1 primers. Among the positive transformants, PPAfXylA-16 was selected for its superior xylanase activity and used for large-scale expression of recombinant AfXylA11 (reAfXylA11). PPAfXylA-16 was initially cultured in 400 mL of BMGY medium in a 2-liter flask at 30 °C and 240 rpm for 24 h. The cells were then transferred to 400 mL of BMMY medium and maintained under identical conditions for an additional 96 h, with methanol added every 24 h to maintain a final concentration of 0.5 % [29,30]. One unit of xylanase activity was defined as the amount of enzyme required to release 1 µmol reducing sugar (D-xylose) per minute from beechwood xylan under optimal conditions. Xylanase activity and protein concentration were assayed via the DNS method and Bradford assays, respectively [31-33]. reAfXylA11 was purified from the culture supernatant of PPAfXylA-16 using high-affinity Ni2+-charged resin. The concentrated supernatant was combined with the resin and incubated for one hour with gentle inversion in an ice bath. The mixture was transferred to a chromatography column and sequentially washed with ten column volumes each of wash buffer followed by elution buffer. The samples were analyzed by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) [34] and Western blotting [35]. 2.2 Enzymatic properties of reAfXylA11 The effect of temperature on the catalytic activity of reAfXylA11 was assessed across a temperature range of 20–65 °C at pH 7.0 for 5 min. The pH-dependent activity of reAfXylA11 was investigated at pH 3.0–8.0 (Na2HPO4-citric acid) and pH 9.0 (Tris–HCl) at 40 °C for 5 min. For optimum temperature and pH measurement, the corresponding highest activity of reAfXylA11 was taken as 100 %. In the thermal stability assay, reAfXylA11 was treated from 20 °C to 65 °C for 10 min, and then the residual activity of reAfXylA11 was assayed under optimal conditions. To evaluate pH stability, reAfXylA11 was incubated in buffer solutions with pH values ranging from 3.0 to 9.0 at 25 °C for one hour; subsequent residual activity was measured under optimal conditions. For these stability assays, the activity of untreated reAfXylA11 was taken as 100 %. For the evaluation of the effects of metal ions on xylanase activity, reAfXylA11 was mixed with K +, Mg2+, Cu2+, Ca2+, Zn2+, Fe3+, Mn2+, Co2+, and Al3+, respectively. The final metal ion concentrations were adjusted to 10 mmol/L and 5 mmol/L. These mixtures were incubated at 25 °C for 1 h The residual activities of reAfXylA11 were assayed. 2.3 Antioxidant properties of beechwood xylan hydrolysates generated by reAfXylA11 A reaction was performed by combining 10 mL of 1.0 % beechwood xylan with 25 U of purified reAfXylA11 and incubating the mixture at 40 °C for 20 min, the reaction was then stopped by boiling it for 5 min. Hydrolysis sample was analyzed using high performance anion exchange chromatography (HPAEC) on the ICS-3000 system, equipped with a CarboPac PA-200 column (250 mm x 2 mm, Thermo Scientific Dionex) and a pulsed amperometric detector [36]. The in vitro antioxidant capacity of the hydrolysates was evaluated, including four key indicators: anti-fat oxidation capacity [37], DPPH and ABTS+ free radical scavenging activities, and ferrous ion chelating capacity [38-40]. 2.4 Characterization of reAfXylA11 inhibition by rePOsXIP Inhibition rate of rePOsXIP on reAfXylA11 was defined as the percentage reduction in activity of xylanase. The influence of incubation time on the inhibition efficacy was assessed by incubating reAfXylA11 with rePOsXIP at 40 °C from 10 to 60 min; subsequently, the residual enzymatic activity was determined. The effect of varying incubation temperatures on inhibition rate was examined by incubating reAfXylA11 with rePOsXIP from 20 to 60 °C, increasing in 10 °C increments for 30 min. To investigate the dose-dependent effects of rePOsXIP on the inhibition of reAfXylA11, varying concentrations (0–393.61 nmol/L) of rePOsXIP were used to incubate reAfXylA11 (0.5 U, 500 µL) at 35 °C for 30 min. The inhibition constant (Ki ) is routinely utilized to quantify the affinity between an enzyme and its inhibitor. Utilizing the Lineweaver-Burk plot, we analyzed the influence of rePOsXIP (0, 79, 158, and 237 nmol/L) on the kinetic parameters of reAfXylA11 to categorize the type of inhibition. The Ki was calculated by fitting linear regression models to the relationship between the doses of rePOsXIP and the resultant slopes of the Lineweaver-Burk plot, in both inhibited and uninhibited conditions [41,42]. 2.5 Analysis of reAfXylA11-rePOsXIP interaction using intrinsic fluorescence spectra Intrinsic fluorescence spectroscopy, a powerful analytical technique, is extensively employed for studying molecular interactions, detecting impurities, and quantifying biomolecules. This method facilitates a deeper understanding of the structure and dynamics within complex biological systems. The purified reAfXylA11 (400 µL, 10.1 µmol/L) was incubated with varying concentrations of rePOsXIP at 30 °C in darkness for 30 min. After excitation at 280 nm, fluorescence emission spectra ranging from 200 nm to 500 nm were recorded, with excitation and emission slit widths consistently set at 5 nm. The Stern-Volmer equation F0/F = 1 + Kqτ0[Q] = 1 + Ksv was utilized. For static quenching, the association constant KA ​and the number of binding sites n were calculated using the equation lg(F0-F)/F = lgKA + nlgQ [43]. 2.6 Molecular dynamics simulations of the AfXylA11-OsXIP system The 3D structures of AfXylA11 and OsXIP were generated by the AlphaFold3 [44]. The amino acid sequence identity between AfXylA11 and BmXyn11A from Blastobotrys mokoenaii (PDB ID: 8B8E) is 77.78 %. AfXylA11 was docked with OsXIP using the ClusPro 2.0 online platform [44]. Employing default parameters, along with assessments of energy, model scoring, and visual inspection, the most favorable configuration was selected for subsequent molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. These simulations were executed using GROMACS-2020.6, employing ff14SB force field and TIP3P water model [45-47]. The simulation was configured as cubic boxes, maintaining a maximum coordinate distance of 1.0 nm between the protein complexes. The system underwent energy minimization utilizing the conjugate gradient method with intervals of steep descent every 1000 steps. Positional constraints were imposed for pre-equilibrium stages, and the LINCS algorithm was applied to maintain bond lengths involving hydrogen atoms within the protein complex [48]. Long-range electrostatic interactions were calculated using the PME method [49], and van der Waals forces were limited with a cutoff radius of 10 Å. Temperature regulation was achieved using the V-rescale algorithm, while pressure was controlled via the Parrinello-Rahman method. Following equilibration through 200 ps of both NVT and NPT ensembles, the product simulation extended over a period of 200 ns (300 K, 1 atm). During these simulations, the time step was 2 fs, conformations and energies were recorded every 2 ps, and a total of 100,000 trajectories were recorded. Post-simulation, the system was adjusted for periodic boundary conditions, and RMSD, RMSF, SASA, and the Rg of the complex were calculated to evaluate structural stability and residue flexibility. The MM/PBSA method was utilized to compute and decompose binding free energy [50]. 2.7 FEL and DCCM analysis of AfXylA11-OsXIP system Free Energy Landscape (FEL) analysis, coupled with principal component analysis, represents a sophisticated computational approach in computational biology and biophysics for elucidating the dynamics and stability of protein-protein interactions (PPIs). This methodology provides insights into the molecular mechanisms that underpin biological processes and interventions [51,52]. The representative conformation of the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex was identified from FEL analysis of 200-ns MD trajectories and was selected for detailed study. To explore the changes in conformational dynamics within the enzyme-inhibitor protein complex, dynamic cross-correlation matrix (DCCM) analysis of AfXylA11-OsXIP complex was performed using Bio3D toolkit [53]. 2.8 Key interface residues and the non-covalent interaction (NCI) analysis Key interface residues are situated at the contact points between proteins within a complex, playing critical roles in mediating, stabilizing, and regulating the interactions necessary for the complex's biological activity [54,55]. These residues typically engage in various types of non-covalent interactions (NCI), such as hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, hydrophobic interactions, and van der Waals forces [56]. Key interface residue pairs of AfXylA11-OsXIP were geometrically optimized using B3LYP-D3(BJ)/6–31 g(d) within Gaussian 16 (A.03) [57]. Extensive NCI analysis of these pairs was performed using the independent gradient model through Hirshfeld partitioning (IGMH) [58-61] in Multiwfn 3.8 [62,63], visualized in VMD 1.9.3 [64]. Using the quantum theory of atoms in molecules (QTAIM) [65], we calculated topological indices at bond critical points (BCPs) and assessed binding energy strengths. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Recombinant expression of afxyla11 in P. pastoris X33 The ORF of afxyla11 gene was 687 bp, encoding the protein (AfXylA11) of 228 amino acid residues as shown in Figure S1. According to predictions from SignalP 6.0 [66], the initial 18 amino acids at the N-terminus of AfXylA11 are likely to constitute a signal peptide. The theoretical molecular weight and pI were 24.5 kDa and 6.27, respectively. Multi-sequence alignment (MSA) analysis identified the amino acid residues E106 and E197 as the catalytic sites. The afxyla11 gene was registered in the GenBank (MT682385.1). Amino acid sequence of AfXylA11 exhibited identities of 99.56 %, 96.49 %, and 94.74 % with family GH11 xylanase XlnA from A. fumigatus Af293, A. fischeri NRRL181, and A. fumigatiaffinis, respectively. After induction with methanol for 96 h, xylanase specific activity in the culture supernatant of the PPAfXylA-16 was 704.0 U/mg. The molecular weight of reAfXylA11 was determined to be approximately 33.0 kDa (Fig. S2). 3.2 Optima of reAfXylA11 and the stability The enzymatic activity of reAfXylA11 was temperature-dependent, reaching its apex at 40 °C, as illustrated in Fig. 1 A. Within the temperature span of 30 °C to 50 °C, the relative activities of reAfXylA11 consistently surpassed 80 %. Fig. 1B demonstrated that the optimal pH for reAfXylA11 was 5.0. At pH levels of 5 and 6, the enzyme maintained relative activities above 80 %. Xylanases from the fungal family GH11 exhibit acidophilic characteristics. The optimal pH for GH11 xylanases is intricately linked to the characteristics of amino acids surrounding their acid/base catalytic sites [67,68]. A homology analysis of mature peptides from 82 distinct GH11 xylanases conducted by Sapag et al. pinpointed a crucial residue at position 100. Here, the amino acids Asp/Asn, which form a hydrogen bond with the acid/base catalyst Glu, are critical for establishing the optimal pH of the family xylanases [69]. In GH11 family acidic xylanases (optimal pH≤5.0), this residue is Asp; whereas, in xylanases with alkaline optimal pH (optimal pH > 5.0), it is Asn. In family GH11 B. circulans xylanase A, the residues Glu78 and Glu172 function as nucleophilic and acid/base sites, respectively [70]. The mutation Asn35 to Asp altered the optimal pH from 5.7 to 4.6 and enhanced catalytic activity by 20 %. Crystallographic studies of substrate-xylanase intermediates disclosed a short hydrogen bond (2.7 Å) between Asp35 and Glu172, markedly boosting the stability of the glycosyl transfer transition state [70]. For AfXylA11, the Asn65 residue, which forms a hydrogen bond with the acid/base catalyst Glu197, is the key residue closely related to the optimal pH. Concerning thermostability, reAfXylA11 displayed stability between 40 °C and 50 °C, with residual activities of 98.8 % and 84.8 % after treating for 10 min, respectively. reAfXylA11 has reasonable stability between the pH values 4.5 and 8 at 25 °C for 1 h In conclusion, reAfXylA11 was an acidophilic and mesophilic xylanase with relatively limited thermal stability. 3.3 Effect of metal ions on the activity of reAfXylA11 Metal ions such as Fe³⁺, Mn²⁺, Al³⁺, Zn²⁺, and Co2⁺, at concentrations of 5 mmol/L and 10 mmol/L, significantly activated reAfXylA11 (Fig. 1C). Co2⁺ and Mn²⁺ at 10 mmol/L exhibited pronounced activation effects, enhancing reAfXylA11′s activity to 233.89 % and 204.57 %, respectively. While 10 mmol/L Cu²⁺ and 5 mmol/L Mg²⁺ inhibited the enzyme. With the exception of Cu²⁺, other metal ions demonstrated a more substantial enhancement of reAfXylA11′s activity at 10 mmol/L. Metal ions exert varied effects on the activities of different xylanases. The activity of XynSc8 was modestly stimulated by the addition of 1 mmol/L and 5 mmol/L concentrations of Ba²⁺, Ca²⁺, and Mg²⁺, with 5 mmol/L Ca²⁺ increasing activity of XynSc8 by approximately 26 % [71]. At a concentration of 10 mmol/L, Co²⁺, Mn²⁺, and Cu²⁺ strongly activated the family GH11 xylanase reAnXylB11, with enzyme activities reaching 225 %, 195 %, and 193 %, respectively. However, 10 mmol/L Ca²⁺ affected reAnXylB11, reducing its activity to 92 % [25]. 3.4 Antioxidant properties of beechwood xylan hydrolysates reAfXylA11 catalyzed the cleavage of beechwood xylan chains, producing oligosaccharides with varying degrees of polymerization (DP). HPLC analysis identified the primary hydrolytic products as ranging from X2 to X6, which was accompanied by additional low-molecular-weight xylooligosaccharides exceeding a DP of X6 (Fig. 2 ). XOs exhibit extensive potential applications within the domains of food, pharmaceuticals, and bioenergy, including X2 and X3, which demonstrate substantial biological activities; they function as carbon and energy sources for probiotics, thereby enhancing intestinal health [72,73]. Moreover, these oligosaccharides display antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, offering potential benefits in the prevention and treatment of various ailments. Continued research on the XOs derived from the enzymatic hydrolysis of xylan by family GH10 and GH11 xylanases is essential for the development of innovative functional foods and bioactive compounds. The antioxidant capacity of the beechwood xylan hydrolysates was quantified using a Trolox equivalent antioxidant capacity (TEAC) assay, revealing that 2.491 mg of the hydrolysate equates to 51.68 µg of Trolox (Fig. 3 A). The free radical scavenging capacity of the hydrolysates was evaluated using both the ABTS+ and DPPH methods. The hydrolysates exhibited varying degrees of scavenging ability for ABTS+ and DPPH radicals in a dose-dependent manner. With a dose of 2.491 mg/mL, scavenging rate of 83.00 % for ABTS+ radicals and 63.86 % for DPPH radicals were achieved, respectively (Fig. 3B and C). The hydrolysates can chelate metal ions; at a concentration of 2.491 mg/mL, its chelating efficiency for iron ions reached 62.48 % (Fig. 3D). This result was significant for the prevention and treatment of pathologies associated with excessive iron ions, such as iron overload syndrome. 3.5 Competitive inhibition of reAfXylA11 by recombinant OsXIP (rePOsXIP) The inhibitory effect of rePOsXIP on reAfXylA11 was modulated by various factors, principally reaction temperature, reaction duration, and inhibitor concentration. Temperature changes minimally impacted the inhibition of reAfXylA11 by rePOsXIP, with the maximal inhibitory rate observed at 40 °C (Fig. 4 A). Within the temperature range of 30 °C to 50 °C, the inhibitory rate consistently exceeded 80 %. After a 40-minute incubation of rePOsXIP with reAfXylA11, the relative inhibition rate achieved a significant level and continued to increase over time (Fig. 4B). A dose-dependent increase in inhibitory activity was observed; for instance, administering 275.53 nmol/L of rePOsXIP resulted in an inhibition rate of 82.80 % (Fig. 4C). The impact of the inhibitory protein rePOsXIP on the enzymatic kinetics constants of reAfXylA11 was investigated based on the Michaelis-Menten equation. In experiments involving various concentrations of rePOsXIP (0, 79.0, 158.0, and 237.0 nmol/L), the Km values for reAfXylA11 were 7.83, 12.72, 20.18, and 24.49 mg/mL, respectively, with corresponding Vmax values of 2.08, 2.05, 2.05, and 2.22 µmol/min/mL (Fig. 5 A). As the inhibitor concentration increased, the Km values of reAfXylA11 for beechwood xylan gradually rose, while the Vmax values remained largely unaffected. The kinetic analysis indicated competitive inhibition of reAfXylA11 by rePOsXIP, with an inhibition constant (Ki ) of 120.98 nmol/L (Fig. 5B). The relatively low Ki value suggests a potent inhibitory effect of rePOsXIP on reAfXylA11. 3.6 Static fluorescence quenching resulting from the interaction between rePOsXIP and reAfXylA11 The reAfXylA11 exhibited the intrinsic fluorescence emission peak at 317 nm. As the concentration of rePOsXIP increased, the fluorescence intensity of xylanase diminished progressively, suggesting that the inhibitor induces a dose-dependent quenching effect on reAfXylA11 fluorescence (Fig. 6A). The calculated quenching rate constant (Kq) was 8.019 × 1013 L·mol−1·s −1, significantly exceeds 2.0 × 1010 L·mol−1·s −1. This suggested that the observed intrinsic fluorescence quenching likely results from a static quenching mechanism, where a non-fluorescent ground-state complex forms between the quencher and the fluorophore prior to light absorption [43]. Under the static quenching model, the KA ​and n were calculated (Fig. 6B). Based on this static quenching mechanism leading to a stable complex between the enzyme and the inhibitor protein, MD simulations and binding free energy calculations can be utilized to explore the detailed interaction processes and underlying mechanisms. 3.7 All-atom MD simulations of the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex AfXylA11 and OsXIP were subjected to molecular docking using Cluspro 2.0. Three independent MD simulations of the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex in parallel were conducted, with each simulation running for 200 ns. Root mean square deviation (RMSD) of the complex remained stable from 120 ns onwards, fluctuating around 3.2 Å from 120 to 200 ns (Fig. 7A). The Rg value of the complex stabilized after 115 ns, averaging 24.06 Å (Fig. 7B). The solvent-accessible surface area (SASA) of the complex remained stable after 100 ns (Fig. 7C). The consistent RMSD, Rg, and SASA values indicated that the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex achieved equilibrium and conformational stability during the MD simulations. RMSF measures the flexibility of individual residues, revealing which amino acids in a protein contribute most to molecular motion during MD simulations. Higher RMSF values indicate greater structural flexibility. The RMSF values of the long U-shaped loop, Lα4β5 (K150-V158, between the α4 and β5) in OsXIP showed minimal fluctuation in the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex, representing the holo state. However, the RMSF values corresponding to these residues in the apo-OsXIP state were significantly higher than those in the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex (Fig. 7D). The binding free energy of AfXylA11-OsXIP was calculated to be −74.3 ± 7.6 kcal/mol (Table 1 ). The contributions from electrostatic (−143.8 ± 3.4 kcal/mol) and van der Waals (vdW, −102.3 ± 17.2 kcal/mol) interactions were identified as the primary driving forces. Additionally, nonpolar solvation contributed modestly (−12.6 ± 0.4 kcal/mol) to the absolute binding free energy, whereas polar interactions (184.4 ± 18.8 kcal/mol) were unfavorable to the binding process. Decompositions of the ΔG and ΔE_ele were performed, as detailed in Table S1. Residues R153, H110, G154, D151, A156, Y152, S71, W103, H148, and Y146 from OsXIP, along with E197, R142, Y199, Y143, S120, W39, Y97, P146, Q200, N144, Y116, G121, N65, and A67 from AfXylA11, were identified as significant contributors to ΔG, each imparting more than −1.0 kcal/mol. Additionally, residues E197, E106, D41, D45, E111, R142, D131, E149 from AfXylA11, and R153, D151, D120, D100, E97, D65, E175, D28, D127, D9, and D53 from OsXIP were identified as critical for the electrostatic energy component. 3.8 Analysis of FEL and DCCM in the MD simulations The representative conformation of the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex was determined through free energy landscape (FEL) analysis, as depicted in Fig. 8A. Observations revealed that the extended U-shaped loop between α4 and β5 (K150-V158) of OsXIP inserted into the catalytic pocket of AfXylA11 (Fig. 8B). This insertion likely impedes substrate access to the active center of the xylanase, acting in a competitive inhibitory manner, consistent with experimental findings regarding competitive inhibition. The R153OsXIP within the loop established a persistent and robust hydrogen bond with the acid/base catalyst E197 of AfXylA11 (Fig. 8C). Additionally, R153OsXIP maintained stable hydrogen bond interactions with critical residues within the catalytic pocket of AfXylA11, such as Y108 and Y97 that are highly conserved throughout family GH11 xylanase (Fig. 8C, D and Table 2 ). The manner in which AfXylA11 interacts with OsXIP closely parallels that of the XYNC-XIP-I complex. Payan et al. (2004) determined the crystal structure of this complex (PDB ID: 1TE1) at a resolution of 2.5 Å [74]. The amino acid sequence identity between OsXIP and wheat xylanase inhibitor protein I (XIP-I) is 42.7 %. The crystallographic analysis of the XYNC-XIP-I complex disclosed extensive interactions between the two proteins. Notably, the π-shaped loop (Lα4β5) of XIP-I was inserted into the active cleft of the family GH11 xylanase, facilitating a robust interaction with both the thumb and the facing palm regions of XYNC. The loop is sited in the mouth of the catalytic cleft, blocking access to the three glycine subsites (−3, −2 and −1 subsite). The crystallographic analysis of the TAXI-I, a xylanase inhibitor protein in wheat, in complex with GH11 Bacillus subtilis xylanase (BSX) revealed that the loop (LCzCterm) of TAXI-I extended into the catalytic groove located between the “thumb” and “palm” regions of BSX. This protrusion increased the minimum distance within the catalytic groove (spanning from residue W9 to P116) from 5.6 Å to 8.8 Å The imidazole side chain of H374TAXI-I within this loop engaged in hydrogen bonding and van der Waals interactions with the two catalytic active sites (E78 and E172) of BSX [75]. To delve deeper into the conformational dynamics of enzyme-inhibitor interactions, DCCM analysis was performed on MD trajectories of the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex between 180 ns and 200 ns. The results revealed that the movements of the residues' α-carbon atoms predominantly exhibited negative correlations, as indicated by the blue regions in Figure S3. Additionally, regions delineated by red dashed circles exhibited a positive correlation in movements between the α-carbon atoms of residues K140-M159 in OsXIP and residues V141-F154 in AfXylA11, residues E235-N250 in OsXIP and residues V124-I137 in AfXylA11, residues H152-G154 in OsXIP and residues E197-S202 in AfXylA11, indicating synergistic interactions within these specified regions. 3.9 The key interface residues and NCI analysis The interaction between family GH11 xylanase AfXylA11 and the inhibitory protein OsXIP is a typical example of protein-protein interaction (PPI) as well as a non-covalent interaction (NCI) [76,77]. The key interacting residues of the AfXylA11-OsXIP complexes were extracted and subjected to geometric optimization. The NCI were visualized using the IGMH method, which highlighted the key interactions within AfXylA11-OsXIP complex as depicted in Fig. 9. The type and strength of these NCIs were illustrated through the area and coloring of contour maps. The isosurfaces corresponding to residue pairs R153OsXIP-E197AfXylA11, G154OsXIP-Q156AfXylA11, and W103OsXIP-Y116AfXylA11 in the AfXylA11-OsXIP system were depicted in blue and exhibited greater thickness, indicating the presence of hydrogen bond. The electron space function within the framework of the quantum theory of atoms in molecules (QTAIM) provides insights into the electron density, ρ(r), at critical points where its first derivative with respect to the coordinates vanishes [65]. The bond critical point (BCP) is indicative of strong interatomic interactions. Topological analysis was conducted to investigate the parameters of the BCP among key interacting pairs in AfXylA11-OsXIP complex. An elevated ρ(r) value correlates with a more robust hydrogen bond. In the complex, all the evaluated key interacting atom pairs demonstrated positive ρ(r) values (Table 3 ). According to the equation [78], binding energy were calculated for each ρ(r), thereby allowing for a qualitative assessment of hydrogen bond strength. The hydrogen bond strengths between OE1E197AfXylA11 H14R153OsXIP, H08Q156AfXylA11 OG154OsXIP, and H13R142AfXylA11 OG154OsXIP were medium. The residue R142, situated in the “thumb” region of AfXylA11, and N65, positioned on opposing sides of the enzyme's catalytic pocket, constitute a gate residue pair of AfXylA11. The gate residue pair enables conformational changes that transition the catalytic pocket between “open” and “closed” states [79,80]. Residue G154OsXIP formed a stable hydrogen bond with the gate residue R142AfXylA11, thereby influencing the “open” and “closed” states of the catalytic pocket. 3.10 Suppression of afxyla11-OsXIP interaction by Y116A or S120A mutations in AfXylA11 Our prior research demonstrated that, beyond the catalytic pocket, the “cord” and “thumb” regions in the family GH11 B. amyloliquefaciens xylanase A (BaxA) are critical for mediating interactions with OsXIP [28]. The mutation Y113A within the “thumb” region of BaxA abolished its interactions with the residues Gln63, Ile115, and Asn117 in OsXIP. Additionally, the T93A mutation in the “cord” region of BaxA disrupted its interactions with the His141 and Trp96 residues of OsXIP. The residue T144, located in the “thumb” region of Fusarium graminearum xylanase FgXyn11C, was substituted with phenylalanine, resulting in the mutant FgXyn11CT144F. The variant exhibited enhanced enzymatic activity and demonstrated increased resistance to the XIP-I present in cereal flour [81]. Based on NCI analysis and per-residue decomposition of the ΔG of AfXylA11-OsXIP system, residues Y116 and S120 within the “cord” region of AfXylA11 were substituted with alanine. 200-ns MD simulations on the Y116A-OsXIP and S120A-OsXIP systems to examine alterations in protein conformation and PPI. The analyses of RMSD, Rg, and SASA confirmed that the structural integrity of both mutant systems was preserved (Fig. 10A-C). In the Y116A-OsXIP system, the “thumb” region (A145-K152) of the Y116A mutant displayed elevated RMSF values (Fig. 10D). Alanine substitution at residues Y116 or S120 in AfXylA11 induced significant modifications in the intermolecular hydrogen bond networks within the AfXylA11-OsXIP system, as evidenced in Table 2. Predominant hydrogen bonds such as W103OsXIP@NE1-Y116AfXylA11@OH, R142AfXylA11@NH2-D151OsXIP@O, R199AfXylA11@OHH148OsXIP@ND1, and H110OsXIP@N-S120AfXylA11@O in the AfXylA11-OsXIP system were absent in the Y116A-OsXIP and S120A-OsXIP systems. The disruption of these intermolecular hydrogen bonds in the two systems coincided with the formation of new hydrogen bond networks at the interaction interfaces between the mutant xylanase and OsXIP. Newly established high-occupancy hydrogen bonds, such as S120Y116A@OG-G108OsXIP@O and R153OsXIP@NH2-N65Y116A@OD1 in the Y116A-OsXIP system, as well as Y116S120A@OHH148OsXIP@ND1, R125S120A@NH1-D120OsXIP@OD2, and N65S120A@ND2-D151OsXIP@OD2 in the S120A-OsXIP system, were observed during the MD simulations. In the AfXylA11-OsXIP system, residues Y116 and S120, located in the “cord” region of AfXylA11, engaged in hydrogen bonding with W103 and H110 of OsXIP, respectively. Mutations to Y116A or S120A resulted in a loss of these residues' capacity to form hydrogen bonds with W103 and H110 of OsXIP, as shown in Fig. 11. In comparison to AfXylA11-OsXIP, the variants Y116A-OsXIP and S120A-OsXIP demonstrated increased binding free energies, registering values of −67.0 ± 4.3 kcal/mol and −65.7 ± 4.0 kcal/mol, respectively, as noted in Table 1. This suggests that OsXIP exhibited enhanced affinity towards AfXylA11. The residues Y116 and S120 within the “cord” region of AfXylA11 played a critical role in modulating the interactions between OsXIP and the xylanase, significantly influencing the interacting dynamics Fig 6 . 4 Conclusion In this study, the reAfXylA11-mediated hydrolysis of beechwood xylan yielded XOs with significant antioxidant activities, suggesting the potential of reAfXylA11 as a valuable biocatalyst for the production of functional food ingredients. Consistent with the behavior of other microbial family GH11 xylanases, reAfXylA11 was competitively inhibited by the rice XIP-type inhibitor, OsXIP, with a Ki value of 120.98 nM. MD simulations and NCI analysis revealed that the insertion of OsXIP's long loop Lα4β5 into the catalytic groove of AfXylA11 is fundamental to the mechanism of competitive inhibition observed. These findings offer potential for designing variants with enhanced resistance to xylanase inhibitors (XIs). Ethics approval Not applicable. Consent to participate Not applicable. coredata.dc:description: Glycoside hydrolase (GH) family 11 Aspergillus fumigatus endo-xylanase A (AfXylA11) was recombinantly expressed in Pichia pastoris X33 and secreted into culture medium. Hydrolysis of beechwood xylan by recombinant AfXylA11 (reAfXylA11) predominantly generated xylooligosaccharides (XOs), chiefly comprising xylotriose (X2) and xylotetraose (X3). These hydrolysates demonstrated significant antioxidant capabilities. Competitive inhibition of reAfXylA11 was observed in the presence of the Oryza sativa xylanase inhibitor protein (OsXIP), with an inhibition constant (Ki ) of 120.98 nM. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and conformational analyses of the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex revealed that the extended loop (Lα4β5, K150-V158) of OsXIP penetrated the active groove of AfXylA11, thereby obstructing xylan from interacting with catalytic sites. The R153 at the bottom of the U-shaped loop, was found to form durable hydrogen bonds with E197 (acid/base catalyst) and Y97 of AfXylA11. Additionally, OsXIP established stable interactions with the “cord” and “thumb” regions of AfXylA11 during MD simulations. The binding free energy of the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex was determined to be -74.3 ± 7.6 kcal/mol, with electrostatic interactions and van der Waals forces being the predominant contributors to enzyme-inhibitor interaction. Further MD simulations demonstrated that the mutation of Y116A or S120A in the “cord” region of AfXylA11 significantly reduced its binding affinity to OsXIP by weakening interface residue interactions. Delving into the conformational dynamics of the AfXylA11-OsXIP complex yields insights into the molecular mechanisms dictating their competitive inhibition. This investigation offers useful basis for engineering mutant xylanases that resist to the inhibitory protein yet retain high catalytic efficacy.
